summary: This is a legal memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team in support of a motion for individual sequestered juror voir dire and limited attorney-conducted voir dire. The document argues that intense negative pretrial publicity and the sensitive nature of the charges necessitate these special jury selection procedures to ensure a fair trial. This is a legal motion filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys requesting that the court allow attorney-conducted voir dire (jury selection questioning) in addition to court-conducted questioning. The motion argues that extensive pretrial publicity and the sensitive nature of the charges necessitate a more thorough, individualized examination of potential jurors to uncover bias and ensure a fair trial.

events.title: Filing of Voir Dire Motion
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team files a motion requesting the court to permit attorney-conducted, individual sequestered voir dire for jury selection.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team argues that an 'unprecedented' and 'tsunami' of negative pretrial publicity has demonized her and Jeffrey Epstein, making standard jury selection procedures insufficient for a fair trial.
The motion seeks individual, sequestered voir dire and limited attorney-conducted questioning to probe for bias related to media exposure and the sensitive nature of the sex abuse charges.
The defense cites extensive media coverage including millions of Google search results, numerous documentaries, podcasts, and books specifically about Maxwell and Epstein.
The document argues that the New York jury pool has been saturated with high-profile sex crime cases (e.g., Weinstein, R. Kelly, Cuomo), increasing the risk of prejudicial preconceptions.
Maxwell's attorneys state they have never spoken to the media, implying they have not contributed to the pretrial publicity they claim is polluting the jury pool.
Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team argued that extensive pretrial publicity surrounding the case created a high risk of juror bias, necessitating a more rigorous jury selection process.
The motion requested that attorneys be allowed to question potential jurors individually and in a sequestered setting, in addition to the court's standard questioning.

The defense cited legal precedents, including United States v. Davis and United States v. Wood, to support the argument that attorney-conducted voir dire is more effective at uncovering juror prejudice.
The proposed attorney questioning was to be limited in time and scope, with suggestions like one minute per juror, to prevent abuse of the process.
The filing indicates the defense had been working on the case for 'well over a year' prior to October 2021, highlighting the case's complexity and duration.
